trials_data.trial_name: Clinical Trial 250-13951-306
trials_data.protocol_summary:
This clinical trial aims to investigate the effectiveness and safety of an oral medication called VDPHL01 for treating female pattern hair loss (androgenetic alopecia).  The study will evaluate two different dosing regimens of VDPHL01: twice daily and once daily.  It will compare these regimens against a placebo to see if the medication promotes hair growth and improves patient satisfaction with their hair.

Women aged 18-65 with mild to moderate hair loss, as measured by the Savin Scale, are eligible to participate.  Key inclusion criteria include good general health, adequate kidney and liver function, and a commitment to maintaining consistent hair care routines throughout the study.  Women who are pregnant, breastfeeding, have certain medical conditions (like uncontrolled blood pressure or a history of heart problems), or have recently used other hair growth treatments are excluded.

The study will last approximately 13 months and consist of two parts. Part A is a 6-month placebo-controlled period, where participants are randomly assigned to one of four groups: VDPHL01 twice daily, VDPHL01 once daily plus placebo, placebo twice daily, or placebo twice daily.  Part B is a 6-month treatment extension, where those initially receiving placebo will start taking VDPHL01 according to their initial group assignment, while those already on VDPHL01 will continue.  Participants will have regular clinic visits (approximately 11) for assessments including physical exams, blood and urine tests, electrocardiograms, photographs of the scalp, and questionnaires about their hair and quality of life. A small group of participants will also take part in interviews.  A final follow-up will occur one month after the treatment period ends.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effectiveness and safety of CIN-102 (deudomperidone) in adults with idiopathic gastroparesis, a condition that slows the movement of food through the stomach.  Participants will receive either a placebo or one of two doses of CIN-102 (10mg or 15mg twice daily) for 12 weeks. The study's main goal is to determine if CIN-102 can reduce nausea severity compared to placebo.  Researchers will also assess changes in other gastroparesis symptoms like vomiting, fullness, early satiety, and abdominal pain.

To be eligible for the study, participants must be 18 years or older with a confirmed diagnosis of idiopathic gastroparesis, including both persistent symptoms and evidence of delayed gastric emptying.  Key exclusion criteria include having a known cause for their gastroparesis (like diabetes or surgery), certain heart conditions, specific gastrointestinal issues, or use of certain medications that could interfere with the study drug.  Women who are pregnant, breastfeeding, or planning to become pregnant are also excluded.

The study will last approximately 18 weeks, including a prescreening period, a screening and lead-in period of up to 5 weeks, a 12-week treatment period, and a follow-up period of up to 1 week.  Participants will attend up to 8 scheduled visits, including a gastric emptying breath test.  Throughout the study, they will track their symptoms daily using an electronic diary and will have regular assessments of their overall health and well-being.  Some participants may also choose to participate in additional assessments to help researchers understand how the drug is absorbed and processed by the body.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase 3 Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, 78-Week Efficacy and Safety Study of VK2735 Administered Subcutaneously for Weight Management in Participants with Type 2 Diabetes who are Obese, or Overweight (VANQUISH-2)
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 3, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, multi-center study sponsored by Viking Therapeutics Inc.  This means that some participants will receive VK2735 while others receive a placebo, and neither the participants nor the study staff will know who is receiving which.  The study will last for approximately 88 weeks, including a screening period, 78 weeks of treatment, and a 6-week follow-up period.  The study will be conducted at multiple locations across the US. 

This study is for adults with type 2 diabetes who are obese (BMI ≥30 kg/m²) or overweight (BMI ≥27 kg/m²).  You must be willing to attend regular study visits and follow the study procedures. Key exclusion criteria include having a history of pancreatitis, certain heart conditions, or currently taking certain medications.  The study aims to include a diverse group of participants, including those of different ethnic and racial backgrounds and those over 65.  During the study, you will receive either VK2735 or a placebo by weekly injection.  You will need to attend weekly visits for the first 33 weeks, then monthly visits thereafter. 

The study will investigate the effectiveness and safety of VK2735 for weight loss.  Your weight, BMI, waist circumference, blood pressure, blood sugar levels (HbA1c and fasting plasma glucose), and cholesterol levels will be measured.  The primary goal is to see if VK2735 is better than placebo at helping participants lose weight.  Secondary goals include assessing the impact of VK2735 on other health measures like blood sugar control and cholesterol levels.  You will have regular check-ups and assessments, including blood tests, physical exams, and questionnaires about your health and quality of life.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase 2, Multicenter, Randomized, Placebo-Controlled, Double-Blind, Dose-Ranging Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of Zasocitinib in Participants with Nonsegmental Vitiligo
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 2 clinical research study sponsored by Takeda Pharmaceuticals to test an investigational oral medication called zasocitinib for adults with nonsegmental vitiligo. The study is designed to be multicenter, meaning it will take place at various clinics and hospitals. It is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. This means participants will be randomly assigned (like a coin flip) to receive one of several different doses of zasocitinib or a placebo, which contains no active medicine. The double-blind design ensures that neither the participant nor the study doctor will know which treatment is being administered, which helps prevent bias in the results. The study will involve a screening period to determine eligibility, a treatment period, and a follow-up period.

To be eligible for this study, you must be an adult with a confirmed diagnosis of nonsegmental vitiligo. The study is looking for individuals whose vitiligo affects a certain amount of their body surface area and is considered stable or active. You may not be able to participate if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, have certain other medical conditions, or have recently used specific medications or therapies for vitiligo, including other JAK inhibitors or phototherapy. Before joining, the study team will explain all the details in an informed consent document, and you will have the opportunity to ask any questions to decide if participation is right for you.

The primary goal of this study is to evaluate how effective different doses of zasocitinib are at promoting skin repigmentation compared to a placebo. This will be measured by the study doctor using a standardized scoring system (Vitiligo Area Scoring Index, or VASI) that assesses changes in vitiligo on your face and body. The study will also assess the drug's safety and its impact on your quality of life through questionnaires. Participation requires regular visits to the study clinic for assessments, which will include physical exams, blood tests, medical photography to document skin changes, and completing surveys about your symptoms and well-being.

You may not be able to participate if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, have certain other medical conditions, or have recently used specific medications or therapies for vitiligo, including other JAK inhibitors or phototherapy. Before joining, the study team will explain all the details in an informed consent document, and you will have the opportunity to ask any questions to decide if participation is right for you.

The primary goal of this study is to evaluate how effective different doses of zasocitinib are at promoting skin repigmentation compared to a placebo. This will be measured by the study doctor using a standardized scoring system (Vitiligo Area Scoring Index, or VASI) that assesses changes in vitiligo on your face and body. The study will also assess the drug's safety and its impact on your quality of life through questionnaires. Participation requires regular visits to the study clinic for assessments, which will include physical exams, blood tests, medical photography to document skin changes, and completing surveys about your symptoms and well-being.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase 1/2, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study to evaluate the safety, efficacy and immunogenicity of an Acne mRNA vaccine candidate in participants with mild acne
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 1/2, multi-center, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study sponsored by Sanofi.  The study will be conducted in Singapore and potentially other countries.  This means that some participants will receive the acne vaccine and others will receive a placebo, and neither the participants nor the researchers will know who received which until the end of the study.  The study aims to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of two doses of an mRNA vaccine for mild acne. The duration of the study is not explicitly stated in the provided excerpt but includes a sentinel cohort followed by a main cohort and a long-term follow-up.

This study is looking for participants aged 18 to 45 years old with mild facial acne vulgaris.  To qualify, you must have an IGA score of mild (grade 2), 10-24 non-inflammatory lesions (like blackheads and whiteheads), and 5-19 inflammatory lesions (like papules and pustules), but no nodulocystic lesions.  Women must not be pregnant or breastfeeding and must use effective contraception or be post-menopausal/surgically sterile.  You cannot participate if you have certain medical conditions like immunodeficiency, allergies to vaccine components, history of myocarditis/pericarditis, chronic illness, bleeding disorders, or severe forms of acne.  Several acne treatments require a washout period before joining the study, ranging from 2 to 24 weeks depending on the treatment.  You should be able to attend all scheduled visits and comply with study procedures.

Participants will receive two administrations of either the acne mRNA vaccine or a placebo.  The study will measure the safety, effectiveness, and how the vaccine affects the immune system.  Safety will be assessed by monitoring for any side effects.  Effectiveness will be evaluated by measuring changes in acne lesions.  Immunogenicity will be assessed by measuring the body's immune response to the vaccine.  The visit schedule and specific procedures are not fully detailed in this summary, but will involve regular check-ups to assess your acne and monitor for any side effects.  The protocol mentions a sentinel cohort which will have a modified double-blind approach where site staff administering the vaccine and some sponsor staff will be unblinded.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase I/II, randomized, placebo-controlled, multi-arm, dose-finding study to evaluate the safety, efficacy and immunogenicity of an Acne mRNA vaccine candidate in adults with moderate to severe acne 18 to 45 years of age
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase I/II study, meaning it's one of the first times this acne vaccine is being tested in humans.  The study is randomized, which means participants are assigned to different treatment groups by chance, like flipping a coin. Some participants will receive the vaccine, while others will receive a placebo (an inactive substance).  This helps researchers understand if the vaccine is truly effective.  The study is also 'double-blinded' (or 'modified double-blind' in some parts), meaning neither the participants nor the researchers know who is getting the vaccine or the placebo until the end of the study. Sanofi is sponsoring the study, which will be conducted at multiple sites in the US and potentially other countries. The study duration will depend on the dose and cohort, but will involve multiple visits over several months.

This study is looking for adults between 18 and 45 years old who have moderate to severe acne.  To qualify, you must have a certain number of pimples, blackheads, and whiteheads, as determined by a doctor.  You must be generally healthy and able to attend all scheduled study visits.  You cannot participate if you have certain medical conditions, like a weakened immune system, a history of heart inflammation (myocarditis or pericarditis), or certain skin conditions.  You also can't participate if you've recently received other vaccines, taken certain acne medications (like isotretinoin), or are pregnant or breastfeeding.  If you are eligible and choose to participate, you'll need to avoid other acne treatments during the study and follow the instructions provided by the study team.

In this study, participants will receive either the acne mRNA vaccine or a placebo by injection.  Researchers will be looking at how safe the vaccine is, how well it works to reduce acne, and how the body's immune system responds to it.  The main measurements will be the change in the number of acne lesions, how your skin looks overall, and the presence of antibodies against acne-causing bacteria in your blood.  You'll need to visit the study site several times over the course of the study for check-ups, assessments, and to receive the study injections. The exact schedule will depend on which part of the study you are in, but will likely involve visits over several months.  During these visits, doctors will examine your skin, take blood samples, and ask you about any side effects you may be experiencing.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase 2, Multicenter, Randomized, Placebo-Controlled, Double-Blind, Dose-Ranging Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of Zasocitinib in Participants with Nonsegmental Vitiligo
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 2 clinical research study sponsored by Takeda Pharmaceuticals to test an investigational oral medication called zasocitinib for adults with nonsegmental vitiligo. The study is designed to be multicenter, meaning it will take place at various clinics and hospitals. It is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. This means participants will be randomly assigned (like a coin flip) to receive one of several different doses of zasocitinib or a placebo, which contains no active medicine. The double-blind design ensures that neither the participant nor the study doctor will know which treatment is being administered, which helps prevent bias in the results. The study will involve a screening period to determine eligibility, a treatment period, and a follow-up period.

To be eligible for this study, you must be an adult with a confirmed diagnosis of nonsegmental vitiligo. The study is looking for individuals whose vitiligo affects a certain amount of their body surface area and is considered stable or active. You may not be able to participate if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, have certain other medical conditions, or have recently used specific medications or therapies for vitiligo, including other JAK inhibitors or phototherapy. Before joining, the study team will explain all the details in an informed consent document, and you will have the opportunity to ask any questions to decide if participation is right for you.

The primary goal of this study is to evaluate how effective different doses of zasocitinib are at promoting skin repigmentation compared to a placebo. This will be measured by the study doctor using a standardized scoring system (Vitiligo Area Scoring Index, or VASI) that assesses changes in vitiligo on your face and body. The study will also assess the drug's safety and its impact on your quality of life through questionnaires. Participation requires regular visits to the study clinic for assessments, which will include physical exams, blood tests, medical photography to document skin changes, and completing surveys about your symptoms and well-being.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase 2, Multicenter, Randomized, Placebo-Controlled, Double-Blind, Dose-Ranging Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of Zasocitinib in Participants with Nonsegmental Vitiligo
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 2 clinical research study sponsored by Takeda Pharmaceuticals to test an investigational oral medication called zasocitinib for adults with nonsegmental vitiligo. The study is designed to be multicenter, meaning it will take place at various clinics and hospitals. It is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. This means participants will be randomly assigned (like a coin flip) to receive one of several different doses of zasocitinib or a placebo, which contains no active medicine. The double-blind design ensures that neither the participant nor the study doctor will know which treatment is being administered, which helps prevent bias in the results. The study will involve a screening period to determine eligibility, a treatment period, and a follow-up period.

To be eligible for this study, you must be an adult with a confirmed diagnosis of nonsegmental vitiligo. The study is looking for individuals whose vitiligo affects a certain amount of their body surface area and is considered stable or active. You may not be able to participate if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, have certain other medical conditions, or have recently used specific medications or therapies for vitiligo, including other JAK inhibitors or phototherapy. Before joining, the study team will explain all the details in an informed consent document, and you will have the opportunity to ask any questions to decide if participation is right for you.

The primary goal of this study is to evaluate how effective different doses of zasocitinib are at promoting skin repigmentation compared to a placebo. This will be measured by the study doctor using a standardized scoring system (Vitiligo Area Scoring Index, or VASI) that assesses changes in vitiligo on your face and body. The study will also assess the drug's safety and its impact on your quality of life through questionnaires. Participation requires regular visits to the study clinic for assessments, which will include physical exams, blood tests, medical photography to document skin changes, and completing surveys about your symptoms and well-being.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase 1/2, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study to evaluate the safety, efficacy and immunogenicity of an Acne mRNA vaccine candidate in participants with mild acne
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 1/2, multi-center, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study sponsored by Sanofi.  The study will be conducted in Singapore and potentially other countries.  This means that some participants will receive the acne vaccine and others will receive a placebo, and neither the participants nor the researchers will know who received which until the end of the study.  The study aims to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of two doses of an mRNA vaccine for mild acne. The duration of the study is not explicitly stated in the provided excerpt but includes a sentinel cohort followed by a main cohort and a long-term follow-up.

This study is looking for participants aged 18 to 45 years old with mild facial acne vulgaris.  To qualify, you must have an IGA score of mild (grade 2), 10-24 non-inflammatory lesions (like blackheads and whiteheads), and 5-19 inflammatory lesions (like papules and pustules), but no nodulocystic lesions.  Women must not be pregnant or breastfeeding and must use effective contraception or be post-menopausal/surgically sterile.  You cannot participate if you have certain medical conditions like immunodeficiency, allergies to vaccine components, history of myocarditis/pericarditis, chronic illness, bleeding disorders, or severe forms of acne.  Several acne treatments require a washout period before joining the study, ranging from 2 to 24 weeks depending on the treatment.  You should be able to attend all scheduled visits and comply with study procedures.

Participants will receive two administrations of either the acne mRNA vaccine or a placebo.  The study will measure the safety, effectiveness, and how the vaccine affects the immune system.  Safety will be assessed by monitoring for any side effects.  Effectiveness will be evaluated by measuring changes in acne lesions.  Immunogenicity will be assessed by measuring the body's immune response to the vaccine.  The visit schedule and specific procedures are not fully detailed in this summary, but will involve regular check-ups to assess your acne and monitor for any side effects.  The protocol mentions a sentinel cohort which will have a modified double-blind approach where site staff administering the vaccine and some sponsor staff will be unblinded.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase I/II, randomized, placebo-controlled, multi-arm, dose-finding study to evaluate the safety, efficacy and immunogenicity of an Acne mRNA vaccine candidate in adults with moderate to severe acne 18 to 45 years of age
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase I/II study, meaning it's one of the first times this acne vaccine is being tested in humans.  The study is randomized, which means participants are assigned to different treatment groups by chance, like flipping a coin. Some participants will receive the vaccine, while others will receive a placebo (an inactive substance).  This helps researchers understand if the vaccine is truly effective.  The study is also 'double-blinded' (or 'modified double-blind' in some parts), meaning neither the participants nor the researchers know who is getting the vaccine or the placebo until the end of the study. Sanofi is sponsoring the study, which will be conducted at multiple sites in the US and potentially other countries. The study duration will depend on the dose and cohort, but will involve multiple visits over several months.

This study is looking for adults between 18 and 45 years old who have moderate to severe acne.  To qualify, you must have a certain number of pimples, blackheads, and whiteheads, as determined by a doctor.  You must be generally healthy and able to attend all scheduled study visits.  You cannot participate if you have certain medical conditions, like a weakened immune system, a history of heart inflammation (myocarditis or pericarditis), or certain skin conditions.  You also can't participate if you've recently received other vaccines, taken certain acne medications (like isotretinoin), or are pregnant or breastfeeding.  If you are eligible and choose to participate, you'll need to avoid other acne treatments during the study and follow the instructions provided by the study team.

In this study, participants will receive either the acne mRNA vaccine or a placebo by injection.  Researchers will be looking at how safe the vaccine is, how well it works to reduce acne, and how the body's immune system responds to it.  The main measurements will be the change in the number of acne lesions, how your skin looks overall, and the presence of antibodies against acne-causing bacteria in your blood.  You'll need to visit the study site several times over the course of the study for check-ups, assessments, and to receive the study injections. The exact schedule will depend on which part of the study you are in, but will likely involve visits over several months.  During these visits, doctors will examine your skin, take blood samples, and ask you about any side effects you may be experiencing.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase 3 Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, 78-Week Efficacy and Safety Study of VK2735 Administered Subcutaneously for Weight Management in Participants without Type 2 Diabetes who are Obese, or Overweight with at Least One Weight-related Comorbid Condition (VANQUISH-1)
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 3, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, multi-center study sponsored by Viking Therapeutics Inc.  This means that some participants will receive VK2735 while others receive a placebo, and neither the participants nor the study staff will know who is receiving which.  The study will take place over approximately 88 weeks, including a screening period, 78 weeks of treatment, and a follow-up period. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of VK2735 for weight loss.  The locations of the study sites are not specified in this protocol excerpt.

This study is for adults who are obese (BMI ≥30 kg/m²) or overweight (BMI ≥27 kg/m²) with at least one weight-related health issue, but who do *not* have Type 2 Diabetes.  You must be willing to attend regular study visits and follow the study procedures.  Women make up no more than 65% of the participants to ensure enough men are included. The study aims to include people from diverse ethnic and racial backgrounds and those over 65.  If you are eligible and choose to participate, you will be randomly assigned to receive either VK2735 or a placebo.  You will need to attend study visits regularly, especially in the first 33 weeks.

Participants will receive weekly injections of VK2735 or placebo under the skin. The dose of VK2735 will be gradually increased over several weeks until the target dose is reached.  The study will measure changes in body weight, BMI, waist circumference, blood pressure, cholesterol, and other health indicators.  The main goal is to see if VK2735 is better than placebo at helping people lose weight.  Other goals include assessing the percentage of participants achieving various levels of weight loss (e.g., 5%, 10%, 15%, 20%), and evaluating the impact of VK2735 on blood sugar, cholesterol levels, and quality of life.  Visits will be weekly for the first 33 weeks, then monthly, with self-administered injections between monthly visits.  You will also undergo regular blood tests, vital sign checks, and other assessments.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase 3 Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, 78-Week Efficacy and Safety Study of VK2735 Administered Subcutaneously for Weight Management in Participants with Type 2 Diabetes who are Obese, or Overweight (VANQUISH-2)
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 3, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, multi-center study sponsored by Viking Therapeutics Inc.  This means that some participants will receive VK2735 while others receive a placebo, and neither the participants nor the study staff will know who is receiving which.  The study will last for approximately 88 weeks, including a screening period, 78 weeks of treatment, and a 6-week follow-up period.  The study will be conducted at multiple locations across the US. 

This study is for adults with type 2 diabetes who are obese (BMI ≥30 kg/m²) or overweight (BMI ≥27 kg/m²).  You must be willing to attend regular study visits and follow the study procedures. Key exclusion criteria include having a history of pancreatitis, certain heart conditions, or currently taking certain medications.  The study aims to include a diverse group of participants, including those of different ethnic and racial backgrounds and those over 65.  During the study, you will receive either VK2735 or a placebo by weekly injection.  You will need to attend weekly visits for the first 33 weeks, then monthly visits thereafter. 

The study will investigate the effectiveness and safety of VK2735 for weight loss.  Your weight, BMI, waist circumference, blood pressure, blood sugar levels (HbA1c and fasting plasma glucose), and cholesterol levels will be measured.  The primary goal is to see if VK2735 is better than placebo at helping participants lose weight.  Secondary goals include assessing the impact of VK2735 on other health measures like blood sugar control and cholesterol levels.  You will have regular check-ups and assessments, including blood tests, physical exams, and questionnaires about your health and quality of life.

trials_data.trial_name: A Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo Controlled, Parallel Group, Multicenter Study of Modified Release RTN-001 In Patients with Uncontrolled Hypertension
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 2b clinical research study sponsored by Retension Pharmaceuticals, Inc., which will take place at multiple medical centers across the United States. The study is designed as a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial, which means you will be assigned by chance (like a coin toss) to receive either the investigational drug or a placebo (an inactive substance). Neither you nor your study doctor will know which treatment you are receiving, which helps ensure the results are unbiased. Your total participation will last approximately 16 weeks, which includes an initial screening and run-in period, a 12-week treatment period, and a final follow-up phone call two weeks after your last dose.

This study is seeking approximately 280 adults between the ages of 18 and 70 who have uncontrolled high blood pressure. To be eligible, you must currently be taking a stable regimen of two or more blood pressure medications, but still have a blood pressure reading of at least 130/80 mm Hg. There are several reasons you may not be able to participate, such as having very high blood pressure (over 170/110 mm Hg), a recent history of a heart attack or stroke, or current use of certain medications like nitrates or alpha-blockers. The study aims to enroll a diverse population, including patients with resistant hypertension who are on three or more medications.

If you qualify and choose to participate, you will first complete a 2-week period taking a placebo to ensure you can follow the study requirements. Afterwards, you will be randomly assigned to take a once-daily pill for 12 weeks, which will be one of three different doses of the investigational drug RTN-001 or a matching placebo. The main purpose of the study is to see if RTN-001 can effectively lower systolic blood pressure. Throughout the study, you will attend several clinic visits (at weeks 2, 4, 8, and 12) for procedures that include blood pressure measurements in the office, wearing a 24-hour blood pressure monitor at home, blood tests, heart tracings (ECGs), and physical exams.

trials_data.trial_name: Clinical Trial 250-13951-306
trials_data.protocol_summary:
This clinical trial aims to investigate the effectiveness and safety of an oral medication called VDPHL01 for treating female pattern hair loss (androgenetic alopecia).  The study will evaluate two different dosing regimens of VDPHL01: twice daily and once daily.  It will compare these regimens against a placebo to see if the medication promotes hair growth and improves patient satisfaction with their hair.

Women aged 18-65 with mild to moderate hair loss, as measured by the Savin Scale, are eligible to participate.  Key inclusion criteria include good general health, adequate kidney and liver function, and a commitment to maintaining consistent hair care routines throughout the study.  Women who are pregnant, breastfeeding, have certain medical conditions (like uncontrolled blood pressure or a history of heart problems), or have recently used other hair growth treatments are excluded.

The study will last approximately 13 months and consist of two parts. Part A is a 6-month placebo-controlled period, where participants are randomly assigned to one of four groups: VDPHL01 twice daily, VDPHL01 once daily plus placebo, placebo twice daily, or placebo twice daily.  Part B is a 6-month treatment extension, where those initially receiving placebo will start taking VDPHL01 according to their initial group assignment, while those already on VDPHL01 will continue.  Participants will have regular clinic visits (approximately 11) for assessments including physical exams, blood and urine tests, electrocardiograms, photographs of the scalp, and questionnaires about their hair and quality of life. A small group of participants will also take part in interviews.  A final follow-up will occur one month after the treatment period ends.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase 3b/4, Open-label Study to Evaluate the Immunogenicity and Safety of mRNA-1283 COVID-19 Variant-containing Vaccine Formulations
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 3b/4 open-label study, meaning the treatment is not masked and both participants and researchers know what is being administered.  This is a multi-center study sponsored by ModernaTX, Inc. and the specific locations will be detailed in sub-protocols. The study duration for each participant is approximately one month. Each sub-study will evaluate a specific COVID-19 variant vaccine formulation.

This study seeks to enroll at least 50 participants per sub-study.  Specific eligibility criteria will be detailed in each sub-protocol, but generally, the study is looking for individuals who may benefit from an updated COVID-19 vaccine.  Important exclusion criteria, reasons why someone might not be able to participate, will also be outlined in the sub-protocols. Participants should expect to attend at least two visits, one for screening/baseline procedures and another on Day 29 (approximately one month after vaccination). Additional visits may be necessary for safety follow-up or if the screening visit is done separately from the baseline visit.

Participants will receive a single dose of an mRNA-1283 COVID-19 variant-containing vaccine.  Researchers will be measuring the immune response to the vaccine by analyzing blood samples taken before vaccination and on Day 29.  Safety will be closely monitored throughout the study, including tracking any adverse events (side effects).  Nasal swabs will be collected at the beginning and end of the study to test for COVID-19. The primary outcomes are the immunogenicity and safety of the vaccine.  Secondary outcomes and exploratory analyses may be included as described in the sub-protocols.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase 2, Multicenter, Randomized, Placebo-Controlled, Double-Blind, Dose-Ranging Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of Zasocitinib in Participants with Nonsegmental Vitiligo
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 2 clinical research study sponsored by Takeda Pharmaceuticals to test an investigational oral medication called zasocitinib for adults with nonsegmental vitiligo. The study is designed to be multicenter, meaning it will take place at various clinics and hospitals. It is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. This means participants will be randomly assigned (like a coin flip) to receive one of several different doses of zasocitinib or a placebo, which contains no active medicine. The double-blind design ensures that neither the participant nor the study doctor will know which treatment is being administered, which helps prevent bias in the results. The study will involve a screening period to determine eligibility, a treatment period, and a follow-up period.

To be eligible for this study, you must be an adult with a confirmed diagnosis of nonsegmental vitiligo. The study is looking for individuals whose vitiligo affects a certain amount of their body surface area and is considered stable or active. You may not be able to participate if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, have certain other medical conditions, or have recently used specific medications or therapies for vitiligo, including other JAK inhibitors or phototherapy. Before joining, the study team will explain all the details in an informed consent document, and you will have the opportunity to ask any questions to decide if participation is right for you.

The primary goal of this study is to evaluate how effective different doses of zasocitinib are at promoting skin repigmentation compared to a placebo. This will be measured by the study doctor using a standardized scoring system (Vitiligo Area Scoring Index, or VASI) that assesses changes in vitiligo on your face and body. The study will also assess the drug's safety and its impact on your quality of life through questionnaires. Participation requires regular visits to the study clinic for assessments, which will include physical exams, blood tests, medical photography to document skin changes, and completing surveys about your symptoms and well-being.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase 4, Randomized, Observer-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of mRNA-1283 and mRNA-1273 Variant-Containing Formulation in Adults 50 to 64 Years of Age Without Underlying Conditions that puts them at High Risk for Severe Outcomes from COVID-19
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 4 clinical research study sponsored by ModernaTX, Inc., which means it is being conducted after the vaccines have already been approved to gather additional information. The study is randomized, meaning participants will be assigned by chance, like flipping a coin, to one of three groups. It is also observer-blind, so you and the main study team will not know if you received a vaccine or a placebo (an injection with no active ingredient), though the staff preparing the injection will know. This multicenter study will be conducted at various research sites and will follow each participant for approximately 6 months to collect important post-marketing data on vaccine performance in the current environment.

To be eligible for this study, you must be between 50 and 64 years of age and not have any underlying medical conditions that the CDC considers high-risk for severe COVID-19, such as cancer, chronic lung or kidney disease, diabetes, or certain heart conditions. You cannot participate if you have received any COVID-19 vaccine within the 3 months before enrolling or if you have previously had a laboratory-confirmed case of COVID-19. The study aims to enroll up to 30,000 participants who meet these criteria. If you are a female of childbearing potential, you must agree to use effective contraception during the initial phase of the study.

If you join the study, you will receive a single injection of either the mRNA-1283 vaccine, the mRNA-1273 (SPIKEVAX®) vaccine, or a placebo. The primary goals are to measure how effective the vaccines are at preventing symptomatic COVID-19 and to carefully monitor their safety. Your participation will involve a clinic visit on Day 1 for screening and the injection, a safety phone call on Day 8, another clinic visit on Day 29, and a final safety call at the end of the study around 6 months. You will be asked to use an electronic diary to report any symptoms, and if you feel sick with COVID-19 symptoms, you will need to visit the clinic for a nasal swab test. Blood samples may also be collected to measure your body's immune response.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase 4, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, Post-marketing Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of an Omicron JN.1 Subvariant SARS-CoV-2 rS Vaccine Adjuvanted with Matrix-M® in Adults 50 to < 65 Years of Age Without High-risk Conditions for Severe COVID-19
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 4 clinical research study sponsored by Novavax, Inc. to learn more about an investigational COVID-19 vaccine. As a Phase 4 study, it is being conducted after the vaccine has been approved for other groups to gather additional information on its safety and effectiveness. This is a multi-center study, meaning it will take place at up to 90 different locations across the United States. The study is 'randomized' and 'double-blind,' which means you will be assigned by chance to receive either the investigational vaccine or a placebo (an injection with no active ingredient), and neither you nor the study team will know which one you received. Your total participation in the study will last for approximately 6 months.

This study is seeking approximately 6,500 volunteers who are between 50 and 64 years of age. To be eligible, you must not have any underlying health conditions that put you at high risk for severe COVID-19. If you have received a COVID-19 vaccine before, your last shot must have been at least 90 days before you join this study. The study is open to both men and non-pregnant women who meet these criteria. As a participant, you will help researchers understand how well the vaccine works in a population that is not currently included in the vaccine's approved use.

If you join the study, you will receive a single injection in your arm on your first visit (Day 0). This injection will be either the investigational Omicron JN.1 vaccine or a placebo. The main purpose of the study is to see if the vaccine can prevent you from getting sick with COVID-19 symptoms. For the next 6 months, the study team will monitor your health and ask you to report any potential COVID-19 symptoms, which would then be confirmed with a PCR test. The study will also track other important health outcomes, such as hospitalizations or any side effects you may experience after the injection.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase 4, Randomized, Observer-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of mRNA-1283 and mRNA-1273 Variant-Containing Formulation in Adults 50 to 64 Years of Age Without Underlying Conditions that puts them at High Risk for Severe Outcomes from COVID-19
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 4 clinical research study sponsored by ModernaTX, Inc., which means it is being conducted after the vaccines have already been approved to gather additional information. The study is randomized, meaning participants will be assigned by chance, like flipping a coin, to one of three groups. It is also observer-blind, so you and the main study team will not know if you received a vaccine or a placebo (an injection with no active ingredient), though the staff preparing the injection will know. This multicenter study will be conducted at various research sites and will follow each participant for approximately 6 months to collect important post-marketing data on vaccine performance in the current environment.

To be eligible for this study, you must be between 50 and 64 years of age and not have any underlying medical conditions that the CDC considers high-risk for severe COVID-19, such as cancer, chronic lung or kidney disease, diabetes, or certain heart conditions. You cannot participate if you have received any COVID-19 vaccine within the 3 months before enrolling or if you have previously had a laboratory-confirmed case of COVID-19. The study aims to enroll up to 30,000 participants who meet these criteria. If you are a female of childbearing potential, you must agree to use effective contraception during the initial phase of the study.

If you join the study, you will receive a single injection of either the mRNA-1283 vaccine, the mRNA-1273 (SPIKEVAX®) vaccine, or a placebo. The primary goals are to measure how effective the vaccines are at preventing symptomatic COVID-19 and to carefully monitor their safety. Your participation will involve a clinic visit on Day 1 for screening and the injection, a safety phone call on Day 8, another clinic visit on Day 29, and a final safety call at the end of the study around 6 months. You will be asked to use an electronic diary to report any symptoms, and if you feel sick with COVID-19 symptoms, you will need to visit the clinic for a nasal swab test. Blood samples may also be collected to measure your body's immune response.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase 4, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, Post-marketing Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of an Omicron JN.1 Subvariant SARS-CoV-2 rS Vaccine Adjuvanted with Matrix-M® in Adults 50 to < 65 Years of Age Without High-risk Conditions for Severe COVID-19
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 4 clinical research study sponsored by Novavax, Inc. to learn more about an investigational COVID-19 vaccine. As a Phase 4 study, it is being conducted after the vaccine has been approved for other groups to gather additional information on its safety and effectiveness. This is a multi-center study, meaning it will take place at up to 90 different locations across the United States. The study is 'randomized' and 'double-blind,' which means you will be assigned by chance to receive either the investigational vaccine or a placebo (an injection with no active ingredient), and neither you nor the study team will know which one you received. Your total participation in the study will last for approximately 6 months.

This study is seeking approximately 6,500 volunteers who are between 50 and 64 years of age. To be eligible, you must not have any underlying health conditions that put you at high risk for severe COVID-19. If you have received a COVID-19 vaccine before, your last shot must have been at least 90 days before you join this study. The study is open to both men and non-pregnant women who meet these criteria. As a participant, you will help researchers understand how well the vaccine works in a population that is not currently included in the vaccine's approved use.

If you join the study, you will receive a single injection in your arm on your first visit (Day 0). This injection will be either the investigational Omicron JN.1 vaccine or a placebo. The main purpose of the study is to see if the vaccine can prevent you from getting sick with COVID-19 symptoms. For the next 6 months, the study team will monitor your health and ask you to report any potential COVID-19 symptoms, which would then be confirmed with a PCR test. The study will also track other important health outcomes, such as hospitalizations or any side effects you may experience after the injection.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase 3b/4, Open-label Study to Evaluate the Immunogenicity and Safety of mRNA-1283 COVID-19 Variant-containing Vaccine Formulations
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 3b/4 open-label study, meaning the treatment is not masked and both participants and researchers know what is being administered.  This is a multi-center study sponsored by ModernaTX, Inc. and the specific locations will be detailed in sub-protocols. The study duration for each participant is approximately one month. Each sub-study will evaluate a specific COVID-19 variant vaccine formulation.

This study seeks to enroll at least 50 participants per sub-study.  Specific eligibility criteria will be detailed in each sub-protocol, but generally, the study is looking for individuals who may benefit from an updated COVID-19 vaccine.  Important exclusion criteria, reasons why someone might not be able to participate, will also be outlined in the sub-protocols. Participants should expect to attend at least two visits, one for screening/baseline procedures and another on Day 29 (approximately one month after vaccination). Additional visits may be necessary for safety follow-up or if the screening visit is done separately from the baseline visit.

Participants will receive a single dose of an mRNA-1283 COVID-19 variant-containing vaccine.  Researchers will be measuring the immune response to the vaccine by analyzing blood samples taken before vaccination and on Day 29.  Safety will be closely monitored throughout the study, including tracking any adverse events (side effects).  Nasal swabs will be collected at the beginning and end of the study to test for COVID-19. The primary outcomes are the immunogenicity and safety of the vaccine.  Secondary outcomes and exploratory analyses may be included as described in the sub-protocols.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase 3, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled Study to Evaluate the Effects of Oral NMRA-335140 versus Placebo in Participants with Major Depressive Disorder
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 3, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, multi-center study sponsored by Neumora Therapeutics, Inc.  It will be conducted at approximately 70 sites across Latin America, Canada, and the United States. The study will last approximately 10 weeks for participants who continue into an extension study and up to 16 weeks for those who do not. This type of study is designed to rigorously test a new medication in a large group of people to confirm its effectiveness and safety.

This study is for adults aged 18-65 with a diagnosis of major depressive disorder (MDD) without psychotic features.  You must have experienced symptoms for more than 4 weeks but less than 12 months, and have a certain score on a depression rating scale.  You must also be medically stable.  Some reasons you might not be able to participate include having failed multiple recent antidepressant treatments, certain medical or psychiatric conditions, or being pregnant or breastfeeding.  If you choose to participate, you will be randomly assigned to receive either the study drug or a placebo, and you will need to attend regular study visits.

In this study, you will receive either NMRA-335140 (80 mg once daily) or a placebo.  Researchers will measure your depression symptoms using rating scales like the Montgomery-Åsberg Depression Rating Scale (MADRS), and will also assess anhedonia (loss of interest or pleasure), anxiety, quality of life, and functioning.  The main goal is to see if NMRA-335140 is effective in reducing depression symptoms after 6 weeks.  Secondary goals include looking at other aspects of depression and how they change over time.  You will have regular visits during the 6-week treatment period, and additional safety follow-up visits may be required.  Several procedures will be conducted, including physical exams, blood tests, electrocardiograms, and eye exams.

trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 4 clinical research study sponsored by Novavax, Inc. to learn more about an investigational COVID-19 vaccine. As a Phase 4 study, it is being conducted after the vaccine has been approved for other groups to gather additional information on its safety and effectiveness. This is a multi-center study, meaning it will take place at up to 90 different locations across the United States. The study is 'randomized' and 'double-blind,' which means you will be assigned by chance to receive either the investigational vaccine or a placebo (an injection with no active ingredient), and neither you nor the study team will know which one you received. Your total participation in the study will last for approximately 6 months.

This study is seeking approximately 6,500 volunteers who are between 50 and 64 years of age. To be eligible, you must not have any underlying health conditions that put you at high risk for severe COVID-19. If you have received a COVID-19 vaccine before, your last shot must have been at least 90 days before you join this study. The study is open to both men and non-pregnant women who meet these criteria. As a participant, you will help researchers understand how well the vaccine works in a population that is not currently included in the vaccine's approved use.

If you join the study, you will receive a single injection in your arm on your first visit (Day 0). This injection will be either the investigational Omicron JN.1 vaccine or a placebo. The main purpose of the study is to see if the vaccine can prevent you from getting sick with COVID-19 symptoms. For the next 6 months, the study team will monitor your health and ask you to report any potential COVID-19 symptoms, which would then be confirmed with a PCR test. The study will also track other important health outcomes, such as hospitalizations or any side effects you may experience after the injection.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase 3b/4, Open-label Study to Evaluate the Immunogenicity and Safety of mRNA-1283 COVID-19 Variant-containing Vaccine Formulations
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 3b/4 open-label study, meaning the treatment is not masked and both participants and researchers know what is being administered.  This is a multi-center study sponsored by ModernaTX, Inc. and the specific locations will be detailed in sub-protocols. The study duration for each participant is approximately one month. Each sub-study will evaluate a specific COVID-19 variant vaccine formulation.

This study seeks to enroll at least 50 participants per sub-study.  Specific eligibility criteria will be detailed in each sub-protocol, but generally, the study is looking for individuals who may benefit from an updated COVID-19 vaccine.  Important exclusion criteria, reasons why someone might not be able to participate, will also be outlined in the sub-protocols. Participants should expect to attend at least two visits, one for screening/baseline procedures and another on Day 29 (approximately one month after vaccination). Additional visits may be necessary for safety follow-up or if the screening visit is done separately from the baseline visit.

Participants will receive a single dose of an mRNA-1283 COVID-19 variant-containing vaccine.  Researchers will be measuring the immune response to the vaccine by analyzing blood samples taken before vaccination and on Day 29.  Safety will be closely monitored throughout the study, including tracking any adverse events (side effects).  Nasal swabs will be collected at the beginning and end of the study to test for COVID-19. The primary outcomes are the immunogenicity and safety of the vaccine.  Secondary outcomes and exploratory analyses may be included as described in the sub-protocols.

The study aims to enroll up to 30,000 participants who meet these criteria. If you are a female of childbearing potential, you must agree to use effective contraception during the initial phase of the study.

If you join the study, you will receive a single injection of either the mRNA-1283 vaccine, the mRNA-1273 (SPIKEVAX®) vaccine, or a placebo. The primary goals are to measure how effective the vaccines are at preventing symptomatic COVID-19 and to carefully monitor their safety. Your participation will involve a clinic visit on Day 1 for screening and the injection, a safety phone call on Day 8, another clinic visit on Day 29, and a final safety call at the end of the study around 6 months. You will be asked to use an electronic diary to report any symptoms, and if you feel sick with COVID-19 symptoms, you will need to visit the clinic for a nasal swab test. Blood samples may also be collected to measure your body's immune response.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase 4, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, Post-marketing Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of an Omicron JN.1 Subvariant SARS-CoV-2 rS Vaccine Adjuvanted with Matrix-M® in Adults 50 to < 65 Years of Age Without High-risk Conditions for Severe COVID-19
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 4 clinical research study sponsored by Novavax, Inc. to learn more about an investigational COVID-19 vaccine. As a Phase 4 study, it is being conducted after the vaccine has been approved for other groups to gather additional information on its safety and effectiveness. This is a multi-center study, meaning it will take place at up to 90 different locations across the United States. The study is 'randomized' and 'double-blind,' which means you will be assigned by chance to receive either the investigational vaccine or a placebo (an injection with no active ingredient), and neither you nor the study team will know which one you received. Your total participation in the study will last for approximately 6 months.

This study is seeking approximately 6,500 volunteers who are between 50 and 64 years of age. To be eligible, you must not have any underlying health conditions that put you at high risk for severe COVID-19. If you have received a COVID-19 vaccine before, your last shot must have been at least 90 days before you join this study. The study is open to both men and non-pregnant women who meet these criteria. As a participant, you will help researchers understand how well the vaccine works in a population that is not currently included in the vaccine's approved use.

If you join the study, you will receive a single injection in your arm on your first visit (Day 0). This injection will be either the investigational Omicron JN.1 vaccine or a placebo. The main purpose of the study is to see if the vaccine can prevent you from getting sick with COVID-19 symptoms. For the next 6 months, the study team will monitor your health and ask you to report any potential COVID-19 symptoms, which would then be confirmed with a PCR test. The study will also track other important health outcomes, such as hospitalizations or any side effects you may experience after the injection.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase 3b/4, Open-label Study to Evaluate the Immunogenicity and Safety of mRNA-1283 COVID-19 Variant-containing Vaccine Formulations
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 3b/4 open-label study, meaning the treatment is not masked and both participants and researchers know what is being administered.  This is a multi-center study sponsored by ModernaTX, Inc. and the specific locations will be detailed in sub-protocols. The study duration for each participant is approximately one month. Each sub-study will evaluate a specific COVID-19 variant vaccine formulation.

This study seeks to enroll at least 50 participants per sub-study.  Specific eligibility criteria will be detailed in each sub-protocol, but generally, the study is looking for individuals who may benefit from an updated COVID-19 vaccine.  Important exclusion criteria, reasons why someone might not be able to participate, will also be outlined in the sub-protocols. Participants should expect to attend at least two visits, one for screening/baseline procedures and another on Day 29 (approximately one month after vaccination). Additional visits may be necessary for safety follow-up or if the screening visit is done separately from the baseline visit.

Participants will receive a single dose of an mRNA-1283 COVID-19 variant-containing vaccine.  Researchers will be measuring the immune response to the vaccine by analyzing blood samples taken before vaccination and on Day 29.  Safety will be closely monitored throughout the study, including tracking any adverse events (side effects).  Nasal swabs will be collected at the beginning and end of the study to test for COVID-19. The primary outcomes are the immunogenicity and safety of the vaccine.  Secondary outcomes and exploratory analyses may be included as described in the sub-protocols.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase 3, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-Controlled, Multicenter Study to Evaluate Azetukalner in Moderate-to-Severe Major Depressive Disorder
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 3 clinical trial, meaning it's one of the final stages of testing before a potential new medicine could become available.  It's a randomized study, so participants are assigned to different treatment groups by chance, like flipping a coin.  It's also double-blind, which means neither the participants nor the doctors know who is receiving the study drug or a placebo (an inactive substance). This helps ensure the results are unbiased. The study is sponsored by Xenon Pharmaceuticals and will be conducted at multiple locations globally.  The total study participation time is up to about 4.5 months.

This study is looking for adults aged 18 to 74 who have been diagnosed with moderate-to-severe major depressive disorder (MDD) and have experienced their first major depressive episode before age 50. You must have a current depressive episode lasting between 6 weeks and 24 months and meet specific scoring criteria on depression rating scales.  Some conditions that would prevent you from participating include having other mood disorders like bipolar disorder, a history of certain mental health conditions, substance use disorders within the past year, or certain medical conditions.  If you are pregnant, breastfeeding, or planning to become pregnant, you are not eligible. During the study, you'll need to attend regular visits at the study site.

In this study, you'll receive either azetukalner (20 mg) or a placebo, taken orally once a day with food.  The main goal is to see if azetukalner is effective in reducing depression symptoms, measured by the HAMD-17 scale after 6 weeks.  Other important goals include assessing how quickly azetukalner might work (after 1 week), its effect on anhedonia (loss of interest or pleasure), and the overall safety and tolerability of the drug.  Researchers will also monitor your vital signs, weight, blood tests, heart function (ECG), and any side effects.  You will have regular visits during the 6-week treatment period and an 8-week follow-up period after your last dose.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase 3, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled Study to Evaluate the Effects of Oral NMRA-335140 versus Placebo in Participants with Major Depressive Disorder
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 3, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, multi-center study sponsored by Neumora Therapeutics, Inc.  It will be conducted at approximately 70 sites across Latin America, Canada, and the United States. The study will last approximately 10 weeks for participants who continue into an extension study and up to 16 weeks for those who do not. This type of study is designed to rigorously test a new medication in a large group of people to confirm its effectiveness and safety.

This study is for adults aged 18-65 with a diagnosis of major depressive disorder (MDD) without psychotic features.  You must have experienced symptoms for more than 4 weeks but less than 12 months, and have a certain score on a depression rating scale.  You must also be medically stable.  Some reasons you might not be able to participate include having failed multiple recent antidepressant treatments, certain medical or psychiatric conditions, or being pregnant or breastfeeding.  If you choose to participate, you will be randomly assigned to receive either the study drug or a placebo, and you will need to attend regular study visits.

In this study, you will receive either NMRA-335140 (80 mg once daily) or a placebo.  Researchers will measure your depression symptoms using rating scales like the Montgomery-Åsberg Depression Rating Scale (MADRS), and will also assess anhedonia (loss of interest or pleasure), anxiety, quality of life, and functioning.  The main goal is to see if NMRA-335140 is effective in reducing depression symptoms after 6 weeks.  Secondary goals include looking at other aspects of depression and how they change over time.  You will have regular visits during the 6-week treatment period, and additional safety follow-up visits may be required.  Several procedures will be conducted, including physical exams, blood tests, electrocardiograms, and eye exams.

trials_data.trial_name: Clinical Trial 250-13951-306
trials_data.protocol_summary:
This clinical trial aims to investigate the effectiveness and safety of an oral medication called VDPHL01 for treating female pattern hair loss (androgenetic alopecia).  The study will evaluate two different dosing regimens of VDPHL01: twice daily and once daily.  It will compare these regimens against a placebo to see if the medication promotes hair growth and improves patient satisfaction with their hair.

Women aged 18-65 with mild to moderate hair loss, as measured by the Savin Scale, are eligible to participate.  Key inclusion criteria include good general health, adequate kidney and liver function, and a commitment to maintaining consistent hair care routines throughout the study.  Women who are pregnant, breastfeeding, have certain medical conditions (like uncontrolled blood pressure or a history of heart problems), or have recently used other hair growth treatments are excluded.

The study will last approximately 13 months and consist of two parts. Part A is a 6-month placebo-controlled period, where participants are randomly assigned to one of four groups: VDPHL01 twice daily, VDPHL01 once daily plus placebo, placebo twice daily, or placebo twice daily.  Part B is a 6-month treatment extension, where those initially receiving placebo will start taking VDPHL01 according to their initial group assignment, while those already on VDPHL01 will continue.  Participants will have regular clinic visits (approximately 11) for assessments including physical exams, blood and urine tests, electrocardiograms, photographs of the scalp, and questionnaires about their hair and quality of life. A small group of participants will also take part in interviews.  A final follow-up will occur one month after the treatment period ends.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase 3, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-Controlled, Multicenter Study to Evaluate Azetukalner in Moderate-to-Severe Major Depressive Disorder
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 3 clinical trial, meaning it's one of the final stages of testing before a potential new medicine could become available.  It's a randomized study, so participants are assigned to different treatment groups by chance, like flipping a coin.  It's also double-blind, which means neither the participants nor the doctors know who is receiving the study drug or a placebo (an inactive substance). This helps ensure the results are unbiased. The study is sponsored by Xenon Pharmaceuticals and will be conducted at multiple locations globally.  The total study participation time is up to about 4.5 months.

This study is looking for adults aged 18 to 74 who have been diagnosed with moderate-to-severe major depressive disorder (MDD) and have experienced their first major depressive episode before age 50. You must have a current depressive episode lasting between 6 weeks and 24 months and meet specific scoring criteria on depression rating scales.  Some conditions that would prevent you from participating include having other mood disorders like bipolar disorder, a history of certain mental health conditions, substance use disorders within the past year, or certain medical conditions.  If you are pregnant, breastfeeding, or planning to become pregnant, you are not eligible. During the study, you'll need to attend regular visits at the study site.

In this study, you'll receive either azetukalner (20 mg) or a placebo, taken orally once a day with food.  The main goal is to see if azetukalner is effective in reducing depression symptoms, measured by the HAMD-17 scale after 6 weeks.  Other important goals include assessing how quickly azetukalner might work (after 1 week), its effect on anhedonia (loss of interest or pleasure), and the overall safety and tolerability of the drug.  Researchers will also monitor your vital signs, weight, blood tests, heart function (ECG), and any side effects.  You will have regular visits during the 6-week treatment period and an 8-week follow-up period after your last dose.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase 3, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled Study to Evaluate the Effects of Oral NMRA-335140 versus Placebo in Participants with Major Depressive Disorder
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 3, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, multi-center study sponsored by Neumora Therapeutics, Inc.  It will be conducted at approximately 70 sites across Latin America, Canada, and the United States. The study will last approximately 10 weeks for participants who continue into an extension study and up to 16 weeks for those who do not. This type of study is designed to rigorously test a new medication in a large group of people to confirm its effectiveness and safety.

This study is for adults aged 18-65 with a diagnosis of major depressive disorder (MDD) without psychotic features.  You must have experienced symptoms for more than 4 weeks but less than 12 months, and have a certain score on a depression rating scale.  You must also be medically stable.  Some reasons you might not be able to participate include having failed multiple recent antidepressant treatments, certain medical or psychiatric conditions, or being pregnant or breastfeeding.  If you choose to participate, you will be randomly assigned to receive either the study drug or a placebo, and you will need to attend regular study visits.

In this study, you will receive either NMRA-335140 (80 mg once daily) or a placebo.  Researchers will measure your depression symptoms using rating scales like the Montgomery-Åsberg Depression Rating Scale (MADRS), and will also assess anhedonia (loss of interest or pleasure), anxiety, quality of life, and functioning.  The main goal is to see if NMRA-335140 is effective in reducing depression symptoms after 6 weeks.  Secondary goals include looking at other aspects of depression and how they change over time.  You will have regular visits during the 6-week treatment period, and additional safety follow-up visits may be required.  Several procedures will be conducted, including physical exams, blood tests, electrocardiograms, and eye exams.

trials_data.trial_name: Clinical Trial 250-13951-306
trials_data.protocol_summary:
This clinical trial aims to investigate the effectiveness and safety of an oral medication called VDPHL01 for treating female pattern hair loss (androgenetic alopecia).  The study will evaluate two different dosing regimens of VDPHL01: twice daily and once daily.  It will compare these regimens against a placebo to see if the medication promotes hair growth and improves patient satisfaction with their hair.

Women aged 18-65 with mild to moderate hair loss, as measured by the Savin Scale, are eligible to participate.  Key inclusion criteria include good general health, adequate kidney and liver function, and a commitment to maintaining consistent hair care routines throughout the study.  Women who are pregnant, breastfeeding, have certain medical conditions (like uncontrolled blood pressure or a history of heart problems), or have recently used other hair growth treatments are excluded.

The study will last approximately 13 months and consist of two parts. Part A is a 6-month placebo-controlled period, where participants are randomly assigned to one of four groups: VDPHL01 twice daily, VDPHL01 once daily plus placebo, placebo twice daily, or placebo twice daily.  Part B is a 6-month treatment extension, where those initially receiving placebo will start taking VDPHL01 according to their initial group assignment, while those already on VDPHL01 will continue.  Participants will have regular clinic visits (approximately 11) for assessments including physical exams, blood and urine tests, electrocardiograms, photographs of the scalp, and questionnaires about their hair and quality of life. A small group of participants will also take part in interviews.  A final follow-up will occur one month after the treatment period ends.

The study will evaluate two different dosing regimens of VDPHL01: twice daily and once daily.  It will compare these regimens against a placebo to see if the medication promotes hair growth and improves patient satisfaction with their hair.

Women aged 18-65 with mild to moderate hair loss, as measured by the Savin Scale, are eligible to participate.  Key inclusion criteria include good general health, adequate kidney and liver function, and a commitment to maintaining consistent hair care routines throughout the study.  Women who are pregnant, breastfeeding, have certain medical conditions (like uncontrolled blood pressure or a history of heart problems), or have recently used other hair growth treatments are excluded.

The study will last approximately 13 months and consist of two parts. Part A is a 6-month placebo-controlled period, where participants are randomly assigned to one of four groups: VDPHL01 twice daily, VDPHL01 once daily plus placebo, placebo twice daily, or placebo twice daily.  Part B is a 6-month treatment extension, where those initially receiving placebo will start taking VDPHL01 according to their initial group assignment, while those already on VDPHL01 will continue.  Participants will have regular clinic visits (approximately 11) for assessments including physical exams, blood and urine tests, electrocardiograms, photographs of the scalp, and questionnaires about their hair and quality of life. A small group of participants will also take part in interviews.  A final follow-up will occur one month after the treatment period ends.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase 3, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-Controlled, Multicenter Study to Evaluate Azetukalner in Moderate-to-Severe Major Depressive Disorder
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 3 clinical trial, meaning it's one of the final stages of testing before a potential new medicine could become available.  It's a randomized study, so participants are assigned to different treatment groups by chance, like flipping a coin.  It's also double-blind, which means neither the participants nor the doctors know who is receiving the study drug or a placebo (an inactive substance). This helps ensure the results are unbiased. The study is sponsored by Xenon Pharmaceuticals and will be conducted at multiple locations globally.  The total study participation time is up to about 4.5 months.

This study is looking for adults aged 18 to 74 who have been diagnosed with moderate-to-severe major depressive disorder (MDD) and have experienced their first major depressive episode before age 50. You must have a current depressive episode lasting between 6 weeks and 24 months and meet specific scoring criteria on depression rating scales.  Some conditions that would prevent you from participating include having other mood disorders like bipolar disorder, a history of certain mental health conditions, substance use disorders within the past year, or certain medical conditions.  If you are pregnant, breastfeeding, or planning to become pregnant, you are not eligible. During the study, you'll need to attend regular visits at the study site.

In this study, you'll receive either azetukalner (20 mg) or a placebo, taken orally once a day with food.  The main goal is to see if azetukalner is effective in reducing depression symptoms, measured by the HAMD-17 scale after 6 weeks.  Other important goals include assessing how quickly azetukalner might work (after 1 week), its effect on anhedonia (loss of interest or pleasure), and the overall safety and tolerability of the drug.  Researchers will also monitor your vital signs, weight, blood tests, heart function (ECG), and any side effects.  You will have regular visits during the 6-week treatment period and an 8-week follow-up period after your last dose.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase 3, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled Study to Evaluate the Effects of Oral NMRA-335140 versus Placebo in Participants with Major Depressive Disorder
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 3, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, multi-center study sponsored by Neumora Therapeutics, Inc.  It will be conducted at approximately 70 sites across Latin America, Canada, and the United States. The study will last approximately 10 weeks for participants who continue into an extension study and up to 16 weeks for those who do not. This type of study is designed to rigorously test a new medication in a large group of people to confirm its effectiveness and safety.

This study is for adults aged 18-65 with a diagnosis of major depressive disorder (MDD) without psychotic features.  You must have experienced symptoms for more than 4 weeks but less than 12 months, and have a certain score on a depression rating scale.  You must also be medically stable.  Some reasons you might not be able to participate include having failed multiple recent antidepressant treatments, certain medical or psychiatric conditions, or being pregnant or breastfeeding.  If you choose to participate, you will be randomly assigned to receive either the study drug or a placebo, and you will need to attend regular study visits.

In this study, you will receive either NMRA-335140 (80 mg once daily) or a placebo.  Researchers will measure your depression symptoms using rating scales like the Montgomery-Åsberg Depression Rating Scale (MADRS), and will also assess anhedonia (loss of interest or pleasure), anxiety, quality of life, and functioning.  The main goal is to see if NMRA-335140 is effective in reducing depression symptoms after 6 weeks.  Secondary goals include looking at other aspects of depression and how they change over time.  You will have regular visits during the 6-week treatment period, and additional safety follow-up visits may be required.  Several procedures will be conducted, including physical exams, blood tests, electrocardiograms, and eye exams.

trials_data.trial_name: A Phase 3, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-Controlled, Multicenter Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of Investigational Product in Depressive Episodes Associated With Bipolar I or II Disorder (Bipolar Depression)
trials_data.description:
This is a Phase 3 clinical research study for a new investigational product for bipolar depression. It is a global study taking place at multiple centers. The study is "randomized" and "double-blind," which means you will be assigned by chance (like a coin flip) to receive either the investigational product or a placebo, a pill with no active medicine. Neither you nor your study doctor will know which treatment you are receiving, which helps ensure the results are unbiased. Your total participation in the study will last for approximately 18 weeks, which includes screening, a 6-week treatment period, and an 8-week follow-up period.

This study is looking for adults between the ages of 18 and 74 who have been diagnosed with Bipolar I or Bipolar II disorder and are currently experiencing a moderate to severe depressive episode. To be eligible, your current depressive episode must have lasted between 4 weeks and 12 months, and you must meet specific scores on depression rating scales. You may not be able to participate if you have recently had suicidal plans, have been found to be resistant to two or more previous treatments for your current episode, or are taking certain other psychiatric medications. The study team will review all eligibility criteria with you to determine if this study is a good fit.

If you join the study, you will take one capsule by mouth each day for 6 weeks; this will be either the investigational product or a placebo. The main purpose of the study is to see if the investigational product can reduce symptoms of depression more effectively than a placebo, which will be measured using a standard depression questionnaire (the MADRS). Researchers will also assess the product's effects on the loss of pleasure (anhedonia), its safety, and how quickly it may begin to work. Your participation will involve regular visits to the study center for assessments, which include questionnaires, vital signs checks, blood tests, and heart tracings (ECGs).
